page.topic: Using HTTP_FETCH to Send an XML POST Request
page.description: XML requests can be sent using the HTTP_FETCH method.

section.description: When sending a request using HTTP_POST, you may receive content type errors, such as the one shown below indicating that the expected Content-type header needs to be "application/xml":
section.example: ? response = body = <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <response success="false"> <messages> <message key="invalid-xml">Illegal Input. Input data must be an XML document.</message> </messages> </response>

description.p: HTTP_POST() is an Xbasic function for sending an HTTP POST requests. HTTP_POST() does not allow full control over the request that is being sent, and it makes assumptions about the type of data sent to the server. It always sets the Content-Type header to *[xb:application/x-www-form-urlencoded]*.
When POSTing any other content type, HTTP_POST() will not work as expected. Instead, HTTP_FETCH() must be used, as it allows any header to be set to any value.
Additionally, HTTP_FETCH() supports using other HTTP protocols (e.g. HTTP/1.0.) HTTP_FETCH() will default to *[xb:HTTP/1.1]*. HTTP_POST() (and HTTP_GET()) only use HTTP/1.1.
In the example below, an HTTP POST request is created and sent through HTTP_FETCH to generate an authentication ticket for accessing the Quickbase API:

section.example:
dim settings as p settings.host = "mycompany.quickbase.com" settings.page = "/db/main" settings.protocol = "HTTP/1.0" settings.port = 443 settings.ssl_on = .t. settings.method = "POST" settings.header =<<%txt% Content-Type: application/xml QUICKBASE-ACTION: API_Authenticate %txt% settings.body =<<%body% <qdbapi> <username>sarah@mycompany.com</username> <password>SomePassword123</password> </qdbapi> %body%
dim results as p results = HTTP_FETCH(settings)

section.description: Once the response is received, the status code must be checked first to verify that the request was successful (i.e. a status code "200") The status code should always be checked when using any HTTP_* function. The status code can be found in the *[xb:response.parsed_headers]* property returned by the HTTP_FETCH() function:
section.note: HTTP_FETCH (or any other HTTP_* function) does not automatically redirect the request when a 301 or 302 (redirect) code is received. You must examine the results in result.parsed_headers.status_code and try the URL in result.parsed_headers.location, if appropriate.
